body_text.text: The ECAT Angina Pectoris (AP) Study is a multicentered prospective study to establish an association between plasma levels of haemostasis parameters and the risk of a coronary event in patients with AP. 3043 patients were recruited in 18 European clinics. Before coronary angiography, blood was collected from each patient to perform 23 haemostasis assays, mainly coagulation and fibrinolysis assays and patients were followed-up for 2 years. After adjustment for other known risk factors, age, sex and drug use, 3 assays, i.e. fibrinogen, yon Willebrand Factor (vWF) and tissue-Plasminogen Activator antigen (t-PA ag) remained significantly (P -< 0.02) increased in the event group. The predictive value of fibrinogen is in line with results of large eipidemiological studies. As plasma levels of the acute-phase reactant C-Reactive Protein (CRP) appeared to be higher in patients at risk, and as CRP was strongly correlated to fibrinogen levels at baseline, the increase of fibrinogen in patients at risk may be due, at least partially, to a continuous low-grade inflammatory response. It may reflect the progression of atherosclerosis. Some of the previously established risk markers can now. be understood in terms of inflammatory reactions. Increased levels of vWF and t-PA ag point to activation or damage of endothelial cells. We conclude that the ECAT AP Study is the first prospective study to reveal an association between haemostasis risk markers and reactions involved in the injury of the vessel wall. Whether increased levels of haemostasis factors in angina pectoris patients cause arterial thrombosis is likely, but definite proof is lacking.

Fibrinogen reagents predominantly used for routine coagulation testing work according to the measuring principle introduced by Clauss in 1957. A common feature of these reagents is the necessity to use prediluted samples for measurement. A newly developed reagent (Behringwerke AG, Marburg, Germany) working as well according to the Clanss method enables to measure undiluted samples over a wide measuring range from 0.8 to >12 g/l. This could be achieved by the use of a peptide inhibitor of fibrin aggregation. It enables to adjust the aggregation speed of fibrin to the desired time frame. Coagulation time can easily be determined by various standard instruments including photometric equipment. Reference curves are about twofold more steep than with the known reagents. This allows for improved precision and accuracy. For evaluation, this new reagent was compared with common reagents for fibrinogen determination (Mnltifibren, Behringwerke AG; Data-Fi Fibrinogen Determination Reagents, Baxter Diagnostics, Miami, FL, USA) as well as the measurement of derived fibriuogen (using Tbromborel S, Behringwerke AG). Anal)'sis wcre carried out using KC I0 (Amclung, Lemgo, Gcrmany), Fibrintimer A (Behringwerke AG), Electra 1000 C (MLA, Pleasantville, NY, USA) and ACL (Instrumentation Laboratory, Milan, Italy). Samples used for evaluation were from normal patients and patients undergoing lysis therapy as well as samples with increased fibrinogen content due to acute phase reaction. The results show a good reproducibility of measurements. Intra-and inter-assay coefficients of variation (%) for fibrinogen determination (g/l) in control and patient plasma samples i.e. with the Fibrintimer A were between 0.6 and 8.9. Method correlation studies using Multifibren and Multifibren U in parallel yielded a good cos'elation of results with the KC I0 (r = 0.928) as well as the Fibrintimer A (r = 0.982). Similar data could be shown for comparison with Data-Fi (with KC 10) as well as derived fibrinogen using Thromborel S on the Electra 1000 C and the ACL, thus demonstrating the good usability of Multifibren U for routine testing in coagulation laboratories. A new method has been developed for the quantitative determination of fibrin-and fibrinogen degradation products (FDP) in plasma. An epitope hidden in intact molecules is exposed after cleavage of fibrin(ogen) by plasmin. A synthetic peptide of this new carboxy terminus has been used for immunization of rabbits. Antibodies isolated by immunoabsorption against a partial sequence of this peptide did not react with intact fibrinogen or fibrin, but recognized equally well all fragments E liberated from fibrinogen (AABB-Ea), crosslinked (E 1 and E2) and non cross-linked fibrin (E3).

In a sandwich-type enzyme immunoassay, the antibodies obtained were used for coating of microtitration plates, and polyclonal anti-E antibodies coupled to peroxidase for detection of bound FDP. The validity of the assay was investigated by incubation of normal and u2-antiplasmin depleted plasma (APDP) with plasmin. The presence of heparin as a contaminant in coagulation test samples may cause abnormal results which may lead to additional labratory tests or inappropriate therapy. Current methods for the removal of heparin, like protamine sulfate or ionic exchanger are cumbersome and may remove also coagulation proteins. We describe a simple procedure for an enzymatic degradation of heparin using heparinase I. This enzyme depolymerises heparin by hydrolytic cleavage of glycosidic linkages leading to inactive split products. The stabilized enzyme is provided in ready to use vials (Hepzym e~ ). Plasma is dispensed into the vial and after 15 minutes the heparin is degraded. The procedure was evaluated in several coagulation assays. In 34 normals the aPTT was 25.4
• 1.7 sec before and 25.2 see after Hepzyme treatment whereas treatment with a commercial heparin adsorber increased the mean aPTT to 28 • 2.9 sec.

In individual samples the change of the aPTT before and after treatment with Hepzyme ~ was between -4.4 % and 4.3 %. In 40 samples from normals or patients on warfarin the baseline aPTT was determined and then the samples where spiked with heparin. The mean value before heparin was 25.1 • 1.7 sec and after heparin addition and subsequent Hepzyme treatment 26.1 • 2.3 sec. similar data have been obtained in the PT system. These data show that enzymatic degradation of heparin in plasma samples does not change the aPTT and PT. It is a very simple and specific tool to get reliable information about the coagulation system in the presence of heparin. Moreover, this enzyme may be helpful for the standardization of the aPTT in heparin monitoring.

Fibdnolytic activity is largely regulated by tissue-type plasminogen activator (t-PA) activity and by a circulating inhibitor, plasminogen activator inhibitor type I (PAl-f). This inhibiter reacts with t-PA in vitro after the blood collection. To avoid erroneous low t-PA measurements in vitro interaction of t-PA and PAI-f should be prevented. A large quantity of PAl-1 is contained in the alpha granules of platelets. It is possible that during blond sampling and processing PAI-t release might cause elevations of its plasma values. Therefore different anticoagulants and temperatures of blood storage on t-PA and PAl determination should be compared. Samples were collected from 10 healthy volunteers (5 males and 5 females), aged 25 -55 years. Venous blond was taken between 7:00 and 8:00 a.m. and divided into 3 different anticoagulants: A-3,8 % tdsedium citrate (Sarstedt); B-Stabilyte tubes (Biopool) containing a low pH citrate anticoagulant which stabilises t-PA activity by blocking inhibition of t-PA by PAl; C-CTAD tubes (Stago). One of each tubes was precooled and after filling placed in crushed ice-water. A duplicate of each tubes was stored by room temperature. Blood was centrifuged 60 minutes after collection for 20 minutes at 4"C. Plasma was stored in liquid nitrogen until analysis. For determination of I-PA and PAl the following commercial kits were used: t-PA concentration: TintElize TM Biopool; t-PA activity: Spectrolyse TM/Fibdn Biopool; PAl antigen; PAI-f Elisa Technoclone; active PAl-1 antigen: Actibind Technoclone. Samples, anticoagulatnd and stored in different temperatures after the blond collection, gave similar values of t-PA antigen. The t-PA activity was higher in Stabilyte-tubes than in citrate as well as CTADtubes, the highest activity was measured in cooled Stabilyte samples. The lowest PAl antigen showed plasma samples collected in coo{ed StabUyteand CTAD-tubes whereas the highest PAl antigen was obtained in citrate plasma stored by room temperature. The slight difference between whole PAl antigen and active PAl antigen in samples collected in cooled Stabilyte tubes indicates a small part of latent and of inactive PAl in this plasma. The results indicates, that the Stabilyte solution prevent the inhibition of t-PA by PAl and the release of PAl from platelets. Blood should be collected in precoold tubes and placed in ice-water immediately after sampling. Stabityte solution is a useful anticoagulant for determination of t-PA and PAl in plasma.

body_text.text: Based upon the original bioimmunoassay concept for determination of t-PA activity (BIA t-PA) by M. Mahmoud and P. Gaffney (Thromb Haemostas 53, 356-359 [1985] ), a modified assay has been developed which offers a straightforward procedure with a total assay time of< 2 hours. Microwell strips are coated with a monoclonal anti t-PA antibody which does not block t-PA activity. Binding of t-PA is performed during 1 h at room temperature and after washing a mixture of plasminogen and the sensitive plasmin substrate S-2403 is added followed by incubation at 37~ Depending upon the t-PA activity, the incubation times may vary from 15 min (0.5-5 IU/mL) to 60 min (0.017-0.6 IU/mL). For proper t-PA activity determinations blood sampling is preferably made in acid buffer (e.g. Stabilyte | Biopool), which prevents inactivation of t-PA by PAI-1 in vitro. Acidified plasma is then mixed with water in the well, maintaining a pH of 6 also during binding of t-PA and hence preventing t-PA inhibition. Using this procedure for pre-oeelusion t-PA activity determinations in 40 healthy individuals (age 20-65), a median value of 0.47 IU/mL was obtained with a range of 0.05-1.3 IU/mL. As a comparison, paraUell sampling in ordinary citrate resulted in a median value of 0.03 IU/mL (range 0-0.5 IU/mL). An estimation of potential t-PA inhibitory capacity is obtained by substituting water with a buffer which raises pH to above 7 and thus allows PAI-1 interference during the binding phase. A four-fold decrease or more of the t-PA activity is associated with strongly elevated levels of PAl-1 activity. Thus, by using water and buffer in parallell as diluents in the same assay, information on both the sample t-PA activity and PAl-1 activity will be obtained.

A newly developed global test system "platelet-induced thrombin generation time" (PITT) in which aggregation and clotting depend on the adhesion and activation of platelets at the wall of the measuring cuvette is shortened in patients with acute thrombotic venous or arterial occlusions. Platalet adhesion to siliconized glass and PITT have been investigated preoperatively, intraoperatively and on different postoperative days 30 patients undergoing general surgery (usually strumectomy) who did not receive heparin prophylaxis, in 56 patients with general surgery receiving heparin or low molecular weight heparins and in 60 patients with elective hip replacement who received unfractionated heparin with two different dose regimens. In patients operated without heparin prophylaxis platelet adhesion was significantly increased and PITT parameters were significantly shortened compared with the preoperation values. In contrast platelet adhesion and PITT parameters remained practically unchanged in the group which received heparin prophylaxis. In the 60 patients who have been investigated before and after hip replacement the mean PITT parameters were markedly prolonged and adhesion was increased on the first postoperative day. However in 25 % of these patients adhesion remained very high and PITT parameters were markedly shorter than normal or than preoperative values in spite of adequate heparinization. Shortened PITT end increased platelet adhesion may be predictors of postoperative thrombosis. In a prospective trial it will be studied whether increased platelet adhesion or shortened PITT parameters on the first postoperative day are indicators of postoperative thromboses. Consequently, a Phase I-Study was performed in humans. Twelve healthy male volunteers received subcutaneous injections of placebo on the first day followed by ascending doses of Aprosulate in the range of 0,25 mg/kg to 2,0 mg/kg body weight on alternate days. Anticoagulant, pharmacokinetic and safety parameters were assessed for 48 hours after each injection. In addition, the activity of extrinsic pathway inhibitor (EPI) and some parameters of fibrinolysis were determined at various time intervals. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and HEPTEST R showed a dose-dependent increase for up to ten hours after each application. Bleeding time was slightly prolonged with higher doses of Aprosulate. Levels of plasminogen, antiplasmin and plasmin-alpha-2-anti-plasmin (PAP) were not significantly effected when compared with the individual prevalues of each study day. Only the plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 (PAI-1) was significantly decreased four and ten hours after administration of higher doses of Aprosulate. EPI-activity showed a dose-dependent increase. In general, Aprosulate was well tolerated.

body_text.text: In further studies, the antithrombotic activity of this substance will be tested in patients at high risk for deep vein thrombosis. Defibrotide is now proven to be a clinically effective drug which is useful in the management of peripheral vascular disorders. Our laboratory has provided evidence on the antithrombotic actions of this agent showing that it produces several cellular and plasmatic actions without exerting an anticoagulant action. Utilizing valid data from both clinical and experimental studies, we propose the following additional mechanisms of this polypharmacologic agent: a. Suppression of the synthesis/release of endothelin from the vascularwall (clinical: decreased plasma endothelin levels as measured by an RIA method). b. Reduction of PAl-1 level (clinical: decreased PAl-1 antigen after defibrotide therapy) c. Reduction of TNF (clinical: reduced TNF antigen level after deflbrotlde treatment) d. Endogenous release of tissue factor pathway inhibitor (experimental/primates: measured by a functional anticoagulant method) e. Increased 2,3 DPG level in erythrocytes (experimental data in primates) f. Decreased PMN procoagulant actions (ex vivo: as measured by global clotting assays) g. Suppression of platelet mediated vascular contractionwithout hemostatic compromise (isolated tissue/rabbit model: studied in a rabbit model using intravenous and oral protocols).

No significant differences in this ratio were noted between cultures grown on patches and those without the patches. All cells were able to oxidatively modify LDL. The degree of modification was established by measuring hydroperoxides, malonaldehyde and uptake by cultured fibroblasts. Significant differences were noted in the degree of modification of LDL by ceils from various veins and arteries. No differences were noted between the same cell types cultured on the patch and without patch. From our studies it appears that polyurethane is suitable graft material for endothelialization. Results: Preoperative levels of sTM (median: 54 ng/ml) were more than twice as high as the values in healthy subjects (about 20 ng/ml). Fibrinopeptide A (FPA) is a specific marker of thrombin activity and can be considered as an index of formation of fibrin from which different degradation products derive after lysis by plasmin. An increased thrombin formation was reported in patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD), but no relation was observed between FPA plasma levels and the extent of coronary vessel damage, while differences were observed in relation to the activity of IHD. Controversial data were reported on the contrary on products of plasmin activity in patients with IHD. Aim of this study was to investigate the degree of plasmin activity with respect to increased thrombin generation by evaluating plasma levels of FPA (ELISA, Boehringer Mannheim Italia, -BMI -, Milan, Italy) in comparison to those of D-dimer, product of plasmin action on cross-linked fibrin (D-D, ELISA, BMI, Milan , Italy) in 10 patients with unstable angina pectoris (group U), in 10 patients with effort stable angina (group S) and in 10 controls (group C) of equivalent age. FPA levels in group U (7.51-_1.2 ng/mL) were higher than in group S (2.9+0.5 ng/mL) and in both groups of patients they were higher than in controls (1.2+0.6 ng/mL, p<0.001). Also D-D levels were significantly higher in patients than in controls (U: 243+89 ng/mL; S:156+42 ng/mL; C: 101+28 ng/mL; U vs C: p<0.001; S vs C: p< 0.005) and higher in group U than in group S (p<0.02). FPA/D-D molar ratio was much higher (p<0.001) in group U than in group S and C ( U = 3.19; S = 1.92; C= 1.23). These results indicate that in patients with IHD an activation of both blood coagulation and fibrinolysis exists. However, in patients with unstable angina, the markedly enhanced thrombin generation is not paralleled by a similar plasmin activity as assessed by levels of D-D.

Blood samples were taken before arculation and at various time intervals after the commencement of simulated CPB. 10 runs were performed for each treatment. Parameters measured included: FXII, IIFXIIa inhibition, kallikrein inhibition, kallikrein like activity and PMN elastase-.al.p.ha-l-proteinase inhibitor complexes (E-alpha-lPI). With heparin, activation of the contact systems occurred. With heparin plus aprotinin and with hirudin this activation was much less. In particular kallikrein like activities and E-alpha-lPI levels were markedly lower in the latter two groups. The least activation was seen with hirudin. Our results confirm that the contact systems of blood are activated during CPB with heparin as anticoagulant, that aprotinin reduces this activation and that hirudin would be preferred to heparin as an anticoagulant in CPB. We have previously reported that activation of the contact systems of blood occurs both in cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) and in simulated CPB in an ex vivo model. Wehave implicated high heparin levels in this activation and shown that both unfractionated and fractionated heparins possess this ability. We have now used heparin coated oxygenators in our CPB model with low heparin levels in blood and compared activation of the contact systems under these conditions with simulated CPB with normal heparin levels. In our model recalcified ACD blood was circulated for 90 minutes in a closed circuit system. Blood samples were taken before and at 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 30, 60 and 90 minutes during circulation. With 0.5 U/all heparin in the heparinised oxygenator microscopic clots were seen after 60 minutes. With 1.0 U/ml heparin no clots were seen. We therefore compared 1.O U/ml heparin in the heparinised oxygenators with 5.0 U/ml in the non-heparinised oxygenators. Heparin levels were measured in the plasma samples together with various components of the contact systems of blood. Haemolysis, platelet count and PMN elastase-alpha-1proteinase inhibitor complex levelswere also determined. Haemolysis was significantly lower as were the falls in platelets in the heparinised oxygenator group. Activation of the contact systems of blood was also markedly lower in this group. Our results show that in our ex wvo model lower blood heparin levels can be used with heparinised oxygenators with beneficial effects on cellular elements of blood and reduced activation of the contact systems.

About 300,000 percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplastic procedures (PTCA) were performed last year in the USA. However, the long-term success rate is only 50-70% due to the smooth muscle cell (SMC) proliferation at the angioplasty site which may result in restenosis. Laboratory results suggest that heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) have an inhibitory effect on SMC migration and proliferation as well as the development of intercellular matrix. Thus long term treatment with LMWH could be beneficial for patients who have undergone PTCA, but little is known about the long-term effects of daily s.c. injections of LMWH. A study was performed to mimic the full anticoagulation during PTCA with unfractionated heparin, followed by prophylaxis with LMWH (Mono-Embolexe) over a 12 week period in nonhuman primates (Macaca mulatta). Blood was drawn at baseline and once a week, pdor to the daily injection of LMWH. The following hematologic parameters were analyzed: RBC, WBC, platelet, lymphocyte, granulocyte and monocyte count, hemoglobin (Hb), hematocrit (Hct), MCV, MCH, MCHC, RDW, MPV, and flow cytometry of WBC's. For platelet aggregation studies blood was drawn 5 hours after the initial full heparinization and once each week, 4 hours after the s.c. Mono-Embolexe injection. There were no significant alterations of RBC's including Hb, Hct, MCV, MCH, MCHC, RDW. The overall WBC count did not change, although a significant increase of granulocytes with a corresponding decrease of lymphocytes and monocytes occurred. This was confirmed by flow cytometry analysis. However, in previous studies with other glycosaminoglycans and saline treated primates a similar transitory effect was noticed. These findings suggest that the alterations of the WBC are related to the chronic stress processes caused by the s.c. injection procedure and not to the drug. Platelet function studies as well as platelet count were unaffected by this treatment. In conclusion, a 12 week administration of Mono-Embolexe as projected for the use in the prophylaxis of restenosis did not produce any alteration of the hematologic parameters in the primates treated with this agent. Elective hip surgery without antithrombotic protection is followed by a high prevalence of deep vein thrombosis (DV-r) with a risk of total DVI estimated at 50 % and of proximal DVT at 25 %. The estimated risk of fatal pulmonary embolism (PE) ranges from 1.8 % to 3.5 %. Therefore, protection of the patient is mandatory. The effectiveness of Low molecular weight hepedns (LMWHs) in preventing such thrombotic complications has been demonstrated. LMWHs have been shown to be more effective than Dextren, than unfractionated Hepadn (UH), when given in a standard regimen (8 times 5 000 IU/day), and as effective and safe as UH when adapted daily to the upper normal range of the activated partial thromboplastin time. Clivadne | (INN: Reviparin sodium, LU 47811) is manufactured from high purity standard Heparin (mucosa) by cleavage with nitrous acid and subsequent chromatographic purification. To cover the first days postop until this PT is reached we give 1-2 Amp of Embolex s.c. . We start Embolex the morning of the operation. Additionally we start immediately postop with a pneumatic compression device on both calves called Flowtron for 1 week. Under this scheme we saw clinically and per phlebography in 220 patients undergoing total knee or hip replacement one calf vein thrombosis and no significant rise in bleeding complications. We are planning a randomised prospective double blind study to further investigate the efficacy of our scheme.

Plasmin-generated APC declined to baseline level after 60 minutes for 400 and after 20 minutes for 2000 nmol/L plasmin. The presence of PCI-urokinase (uPA) and PCI-tissue kallikrein (TK) complexes in seminal plasma was analyzed using ELISAs specific for these complexes: monoclonal IgG against PCI or TK was immobilized on a microtiter plate and following incubation with the samples, bound uPA-PCI or TK-PCI complexes were quantified with a peroxidase-linked moaoclo-Hal antibody to uPA or PCI, respectively. Using these assays, we found that uPA-PCI and TK-PCI complexes were present in the seminal plasma from normal donors. These results, together with data showing that PCI forms a complex with prostate specific antigen in seminal plasma (Espafia F et ah Thromb Res 1991) , suggest that PCI inhibits many proteases present in semen. body_text.text: Vitronectin (VN) is a multifunctional adhesive glycoprotein present in the circulation (plasma form) as well as associated with the extracellular matrix of different tissues (heparin-binding multimeric form). VN mediates RGD-dependent cell adhesion and plays an important regulatory role in the immune system and in haemostasis. Initial plasmin cleavage of VN generates a 61 kDa fragment which lacks binding sites for heaprin and plasminogen activator inhibitor type-l, but displays enhanced binding for plasminogen. To further characterize its structure and biological functions, we isolated the intermediate 61 kDa plasmin cleavage product by anion exchange chromotography. Treatment of the 61 kDa fragment as well as a synthetic 15-mer peptide derived from its carboxy-terminus with carboxypeptidase B drastically reduced binding to plasminogen. These results indicate the involvement of a critical carboxy-terminal lysine in plasminogen binding, a structural motif found in other plasminogen-binding proteins. The isolated 61 kDa fragment mediated adhesion to cells, bearing the VN receptor ~8~ in a timeand concentration-dependent manner similar to intact VN, whereas the fragment lacked the ability to muitimerize. Prolonged plasmin degradation of VN revealed loss of the epitope for monoclonal antibody 8E6 which occured earlier with multimeric VN. Finally, the major proteolysis products were a 35 kDa fragment for plasma VN and a 40 kDa fragment for multimeric VN. The occurance of both fragments correlated well with total loss in cell adhesive function. Our findings indicate that partial plasmin proteolysis may convert VN from an anti-into a profibrinolytic component, and that ongoing proteolysis destroys the RGDdependent attachment domain. We suggest that these mechanisms are transiently operative at cell-matrix sites where pericellular proteolysis has to be strictly regulated.

Internalized 125-l-fibrin, characterized as cell-associated radioactivity resistant to proteolytic degradation, was generally only temporarily detectable between two and eight hours after application. Studies with centrifuged platelets revealed the requirement of a plasma factor for the binding of 125-I-fibrin. The reaction was inhibited by hirudin, D-Phe-Pro-Arg-CH 2 C1 or heparin. The plasma factor was purified by various steps including adsorption onto barium citrate. It migrated in SDS-PAGE under non-reducing and reducing conditions identical with prothrombin. Authentic prothrombin also mediated binding of 125-I-fibrin to centrifuged platelets and improved internalization by a thrombocyte concentrate. Inhibition studies suggested that prothrombin first is converted at the platelet surface to thrombin which is the direct mediator of fibrin binding. Failure of inhibiting the platelet-fibrin interaction by RGD-peptides or by an antibody directed against the GPIIb/IIIa-complex suggests that this transmembrane complex is not involved in fibrin clearance. We investigated the presence of tPA-binding proteoglycans (PG) on human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC). Roughly 6% of total radioactivity, present in the cell extract of [35S] labelled HUVEC, could be eluted from DFP treated tPA-Sepharose 4B. No binding was observed using a BSA-Sepharose 4B. Using an urea electrophoresis [35]S radioactivity revealed one major signal with a Mr between 600 to 750 kDa (PG-A). Two additional bands were visible ranging from 340 to 440 (PG-B) and 120 to 180 kDa (PG-C). Preincubation of the eluted material with glycosaminoglycan (GAGIdigesting enzymes followed by PAGE showed that heparan sulfate like PG are the major GAG in the elated material. Incubation of the material with heparitinase inhibited also rebinding of eluted material to tPA-Sepharose 4B, supporting that the major carbohydrate component of the PG responsible for the interaction with tPA might be composed of heparan sulfate. This was confirmed by testing the rebinding behaviour after nitrous acid degradation which was nearly abolished. Beparin, arginine and lysine, but not glycine, EACA and aspartic acid were effective agents to inhibit rebinding of eluted material to tPA-Sepharose 4B. Elution of rebound material was possible with the same components which were active as inhibitors of rebinding. Our results suggest that binding of tPA to HUVEC might be mediated by heparan sulfate-like PG, which may function as a storage pool for tPA that can be depleted by plasma heparin. Introduction: Aqulred vWD is a rare disorder associated with angiodysplasia or malignant proliferative diseases. In the latter this disorder does not respond to treatment of the underlying disease. For the first time we report on a patient with a malignant lymphoma associated vWD which disappeared after BMT. Case report: The 48 year old woman suffering from lmmunocytoma (without paraproteinemia) received bone marrow from her HLA-identical, MLC-noareactive sister atier total body irradiation (TBI, 12Gy) and high dose IV Etoposide (60 mg/kg). Since diagnosis of her disease in 1986 she was interminingly treated with cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, prednisolon, vinblastin and, because of progressive disease, adriamycin, vincristin, bendamustin and methotrexate (MTX). Easy bruising and a sudden onset of severe epistaxis shortly after the lymphoma was discovered led to the diagnosis of vWD. Since she never had bleeding problems until 1986 and her family history did not indicate any congenital bleeding disorder her vWD must have been aquired. During the following period repeat bleeding episodes were controlled by infusion of cryoprezipitate. Three weeks before BMT an Hickman-catheter was inserted uneventfully after prophylactic therapy with FVIII/vWF concentrate (Haemate, Behringwerke). Despite prophylactic treatment with cyclosporin A (CSA) and a short course of MTX, on day *23 the patient developed skin-GVHD which responded fully to prednisoloa. BMT was followed by complete remission of the lymphoma and a gradual disappearance of the aquired vWD (see table) . Discussion: Although we do not know the underlying mechanism which led to the normalization of coagulation we suggest that eradication of the malignant lymphatic cell clone by high dose chemotherapy and TBI is the crucial event. The possibility that CSA is a contributing or even essential factor in this setting cannot be ruled out. (1992) Purity is a main feature in discussions on the quality of FVIII concentrates. Conflicting data exist, either supporting or questioning its clinical relevance. The terms "purity" and "impurities" are not well defined. Specific activity describing the potency per amount of protein is an attractive parameter, but covers only the quantitative aspect. For instance, albumin added as a stabilizer and yon Willebrand factor (vWF) protein cannot be considered as contaminants, but would account for most of the protein in the calculation of specific activity for many concentrates. Whereas data are generally corrected for albumin content, vWF components are often ignored. VWF represents 99% of the molecular weight of an intact FVIII molecule with 10 p.g/ml plasma as compared to only 1% for the FVIII:C component with 0.1 p.g/mi plasma (Furie & Furie, 1988) . A product with a v .~.~Ag._/FVI!!:C ratio of 1:1 (as in plasma) may theoretically reach a specific activity of no more than 100 IU/mg total protein, where all the protein represents FVIII. For a product in which the vWFAg has been reduced to a ratio of 0.hl, the maximum specific activity would rise to above 900 IU/mg. The vWFAg/FVIII:C ratios of presently available concentrates have been shown to vary by a factor of 100, so that the vWFAg content has a great impact on the value of specific activity given for an individual preparation. Thus, specific activity values are misleading when used for comparing purity of FVIII concentrates. Although it is unclear whether the vWF component of the FVIII molecule is of beneftt to hemophiliac patients with normal vWF, there is evidence that it contributes to the stability of the FVIII molecule. In conclusion, the classification of FVIU products on the basis of specific activity without considering the vWFAg content is not satisfactory.

Objective: To evaluate whether the hepatitis A cases which recently occurred in 85 hemophilic patients from four European countries ( Italy,Germany, Irland and Belgium ) were acquired through trasfusion or the enteric route. Design : A case-control study based upon the Italian cohort. Setting: Twenty-eight hemophilia treatment centers in Italy. Patients: The first 29 consecutive hemophiliacs who developed hepatitis A jaundice were compared with one to three non-jaundiced hemophiliacs matched to cases by age, province of residence, type and severity of hemophilia and lifetime exposure to factor VIII concentrates. Measurements: Type of concentrate and batches infused, number of doses,, contacts with individuals who had jaundice or were diagnosed to have hepatitis A, travels abroad to countries reported to have a high attack rate for hepatitis A, consumption of raw shellfisch. Main results : Cases Were no more or less likely than controls to have travelled to high-risk countries, to have consumed raw shellfish or to have had contacts with jaundiced individuals. Cases were much more likely than controls to have used a factor VIII concentrate virus-inactivated with a solvent/detergent misture (odds ratio, 38;95 C1 1.8 to more than 1,000) and to have been infused with larger doses of the concentrate during the presumed incubation period of hepatitis A (odds ratio, 42; C1 6 to 196). Conclusions: In the Italian cohort, hepatitis A was transmitted by a factor VIII concentrate treated with a virusidal method (solvent/detergent) that is ineffective in inactivating nonenveloped viruses.

body_text.text: COMPARISON OF THE AUTOMATED COAGULATION ANALYZERS ACL 300 R AND ELECTRA 1000 C KH BECK; T SCHULZKI; V LINK; V KRETSCHMER Optical coagulation measurements with ACL and Electra are performed by using a nephelometric or turbidimctric detection method of clot formation respectively. Application of chromogenic substratcs are also possible in both systems. We compared both analyzers by linear regression analysis in patients with normal and pathologic values of aPTT, PT (n=50), fibrinogen (derived) and plasminogen (n=20, chromogenic assay). Derived fibrinogen was compared with the method of Clauss on Sehnitger coagulometer. Moreover we focused our interest on the sensitivity of both systems (nephelomctric, lurbidimetric) in the highly pathologic range of clotting parameters by geometric dilution of all factors of the extrinsic and intrinsic system with factor deficient plasma from 100% to 0.5% of clotting activity and by measuring the aPTT of stable heparinized patients with aPTT between 36 and 100 sec, and PT measurements of different normal and pathologic control plasmas (n=10, each series). Assay conditions were the same in both ACL and Electra, respectively. Methods were adapted according to recommendations of the manufactarers. Statistical analysis has been done by using paired student's t-test. PT and aPTT showed good correlation coefficients (r=0.99 and r=0.98, rasp.), whereas those of fibrinogen and plasminogen were slightly lower (r=0.93 and r=-0.92, resp.). Within run precision of all tests were comparable in both analyzers yielding variation coefficients between 1 and 5% (independent of the pathologic range). Derived fibrinogen measured by the optical systems showed no significant difference to the mechanically determined fibrinogen with the Clanss method. Accuracy of determination deteriorated significantly in the highly pathologic range, and sometimes Electra 1000 displayed no dot detection, although the value was within the range of the standard curve. ACL showed clearly longer aPTT values in heparinized patients than Electra. In conclusion, both systems are applicable for routine determination methods. In contrast to ACL 300, Electra 1000 C falls in continuous clot detection in the high pathologic range which is of disadvantage in special coagulation disorders. Plasminogen activator inhibitor {PAl-11 is a glu with a molecular weight of 50.000 Dalton. It is a member of the serine protease inhibitor (SERPIN) with homologies to other serine protease inhibitors. PAl-1 is an acute phase protein and the concentration is correlated to Interleukin I level. Elevated PAl-1 levels will be observed in patients with thrombotic disorders (deep vein thrombosis, myocardial infarction, stroke), some malignancies and septicaemia. The PAI-1antigen-ELISA can be used to measure the antigen levels in plasma. We compared the PAl-l-antigen-ELlSA-test from TechnoCIone/Vienna and the IMMUNOZYM PAl-1 from IMMUNO/Heidelberg which use the same monoclonal antibodies anti-PAl-t immobilised onto plastic microtiter strips, anti-PAl-I conjugates to peroxidase and the same PAl-1 antigen as calibrator.

The PAI-1-ELISA tests measure free, complexed and latent PAl-1 and it is not affected oy ot•er ptasm~nogen activator inhibitors. The monoclonal antibodies do not show an,/ eross-reactivities to other plasma components as single or double stranded DNA, collagen, Keratin and ENA (extractable nuclear antigens). The range in the tests is 1.0 -30 ng/mL The intra-and interassay variations are less than 5 and 10 %, respectively.

The two assays were compared with a standard panel of plasma of healthy donors and plasma of patients with thrombotic disorders. Normal plasma PAl-1 levels are 30 -80 ng/ml, The non parametric evaluation according to Bablock and Passing evidenced the equivalence of the two test systems. Tissue-type plasminogen activator (t-PA) is a 70.000 Dalton glycoprotein which serves as the major activator of the blood fibrinolytic system. The measurement of t-PA can be used to quantitate t-PA antigen levels in patients with thrombotic tendencies or bleeding disorders. We compared the t PA antigen EUSA-test from TechnoCIone/Vienna and the IMMUNOZYM t-PA from IMMUNO/Heidelberg which use different anti t-PA antibodies immobilised onto plastic microtiter strips, but the same peroxidase-labelled monoclonal antibody and the same rt-PA as antigen.

The t-PA ELISA-tests measure both free t-PA and t-PA-PAI complexes. The monoclonal antibody does not show any cross-reaetivities against other plasma components as single or douhle stranded DNA, collagen, Keratiq and _FN~ (extractable nuclear antigens). The tests are not affected by other plasminogen activators. The range in the tests is 0.3 -2.5 ng/ml. The intra-and interassay variations are less than 5 and 10 %, respectively.

Extra-corporeal drcalation (ECC) in cardiosur#cal intervention requires high dose heparinisation for the inhibition of the dotting cascade that is activated both through damage to the vessel (extrinsic) land through the blood coming into contact with various artificial surfaces (intrinsic pathway). The activation of the fibrinolytic system thus inevitably caused is in most heart eentres nowadays reduced through the application of the proteinase inhibitor aprotinin (Trasylol, Bayer/Germany). The necessary monitoring of anticoagulation during ECC is carried out with the activated whole blood clotting time (ACT). The two machines used for this at present, Hemotec (Englewood, Colorado/USA) and Hemochron (Edison, N.J./USA), function with the different contact phase activators kaolin (clay = hydrated aluminium silicate) and eelite (ldeselgur = diatom earth). These two activators display highly significant differences (t-test, p<0.01) during ECC both in the pure in vitro tests (modified ~ with whole blood in a neutral eoab, ulometer, n= 14) as well as in parallel measurement with patient blood (n=20) with the two original machines. The Hemotec machine with kaolin as activator showed no effect due to aprotinin application during the whole duration of surgery while with the Hemochron machine almost double the dottin$ time was re$istered as soon as the combination of aprotimn -heparin crusted. Measurement errors arising from the technical limitations of the machines themselves explain the effects of aprotinin as often described in the literature regards a prolongation of the ACT, the sul3sequent anticoagulant properties and thus possible heparin reduction during ECC; these errors should be corrected as quickly as possible.

body_text.text: Protein S (PS) deficiency is associated with an increased risk of developing thrombeembelie diseases. Until recently, PS deficiency had to be diagnosed by the determination of PS antigen concentration. For a few months PS activity (PS Act) assays have become commercially available. However, few experiences on the routine application of those new assays have been published. Therefore, the results of the first PS Act determinations performed in our laboratory with assay kits from three manufacturers are presented in comparison with the dam evaluated by our standard PS antigen (PS Ag) assay. Citrate blood plasma samples obtained from 100 individuals with thrombotic or thrombuembolic events were analysed for the PS levels. PS ACt determinations were done using Protein S Activity Assay [A] (Behring), Protein S Clotting-Test [B] (Boeininger Mannhaim/Diagnostica Stage) and IL Test TM Protein S [(2] (Immnnentation Laboratory). The concentrations of total PS and of free PS Ag were determined by Protein S-ELISA (Boehringer Mannheim]Diagnosfica Stage), respectively. The results of the activity and antigen assays were compared by linear regression analysis. The regression data (y (PS Ac 0 = a + bX (PS Ag)) with X = total PS Ag yielded for A: a=29.6, b---0.500, correlation coefficient 1"=0.448 (N=74), for B: a=19.4, b=0.653, I"=-0.561 (N=79), and for C: a=19.7, b=0.767, 1"=-0.725 (N=71). With X = free t'S Ag for A: a=43.3_, b=0.474, r=-0.374 (N=79), for B: a=18.1, 1,--0.928, r=0.664 (N=84), and for C: a=36.2, b=0.761, r=0.60 (N=72) were found. PS ACt and PS Ag levels above the upper cot-off level of 125% were excluded from the analysis. The data of PS Act obtained by assays B and C correlated fairly well with total and free PS Ag (r> 0.55). The best correspondence was observed gor assay B compared with free PS Ag, as indicated by the slope b=0.928 of the regression curve. Th~ was confirmed by the finding that among the 10 samples exhibiting total PS Ag below the normal range (70-120 %) together with free PS Ag or PS Act below 40 % of normal 5 samples yielded nearly equal PS Act and free PS Ag values (_+ 10 %). Nevertheless, due to the small amber of samples analysed it is too early to conclude, that assay B might be the most sensitive assay for the determination of free PS activity. Further investigations have to be done also in order to characterize the sensitivities of assays A and B with respect to total and free PS Ag.

A new F XlII assay (Berichrom F XIII, Behring Werke AG, Germany) permits the measurement of F XIII in untreated and undiluted plasma. Acquired partial deficiency of F XIII has been reported in association with severe liver disease and DIC. Therefore, F XIII deficiency may play a role in the increased bleeding tendency during orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) as in parallel to end-stage liver disease a DIC-like state is observed intraoperatively. Materials and methods: Arterial blood samples were collected at 7 different timepoints during 10 OLTs. In addition a sample of the perfusate released from the graft was taken when the graft was floaded with the recipiant's systemic blood. F XIII activity was determined using the established clot solubility test (Behring) as well as the photometric F XIII assay. Results: The performance of the photometric test took only a tenth of time as compared to the clot solubility test. It demonstrated a very good withinrun and day to day precision. A highly significant correlation between the two assays (p <0.01) was observable. Preoperative F XIII activity were in the lower part of the normal range. With beginning of the anhepatic phase a significant decrease of F XIIl activity was seen (p=0.04) followed by a short but insignificant increase in the early reperfusion phase and by a significant decrease 10 minutes later (p=0.02). In 7 patients F XIII activity levels in the perfusate were far higher than in the systemic circulation (p=0.07). Conclusion: The fast photometric F XIII assay showed a high precision and a good correlation to the clot solubility test. The decrease of F Xlll activity in the anhepatic phase is probably due to increased fibrinolysis. Higher F XIII activity levels in the graft liver perfusate and the increase of F XIII activity with starting reperfusion suggest a hepatic release of F XIII. investigations may be hampered without the knowledge of the clotting and fibrinolytic system of the laboratory animal used. With diagnostics for the determination of clotting factors and fibrinotytic parameters in hunmn plasma, samples from rat, guinea pig, rabbit, cat, dog, sheep, cattle, horse, pig~and monkey were analysed, The human system was employed even for standard curves and controls. Results obtained in this way are relative values in relation to pooled fresh human plasma of healthy donors uhich is defined to have 100 X of the norm or 1 unit of each factor per 1 mr. Under these conditions marked differences between the human clotting system and those of different animal species appear. Thus~ rabbits have an about 50 times higher activity of factor V than humans, and guinea pigs only 6 X of the factor VII activity of human plasma. Plasma levels of fibrinogen and~'2-antiptasmin in plasma samples of the investigated animal species are in the range of human plasma. Differences in the plasma levels of single factors as compared to human plasma are reflected by the clotting times of the screening tests. For the determination of ptasminogen, streptokinase was used as activator of the fibrinotytic system. Hence, the results obtained by this method merely represent the activatabitity of the animal plasminogen in comparison to the human system, and thus do not allow statements concerning the real plasminogen content of the plasma sample from the animal species. The implications of the results for pharmacological investigations are dicussed. The analyzers characteristics can be described as follows: 1. All traditional clotting tests including the determination of single factors, Antithrombin III, Protein C and Protein S can be performed with random as well as continous access (including stat function) using primary sample cups. 2. Clot formation is detected optu-mechanically: the developing clot in the measuring cuvette is centered by magnetic stirring and the onset of coagulation is determined by detecting the fibrin thread formation in the light path of the optical unit. Therefore samples known to disturb photooptical coagulation measurement, i.e. turbidic samples, can be measured without any problems. For evaluation this new system was compared with other analyzers used for coagulation testing (ACL, Instrumentation LaboratoD,, Milan, Italy; Electra 1000 C, MLA, Pleasantville, NY, USA; KC l0 and KC 40, Amelnng, Lemgo, Germany). While reagents from Behringwerke were used for operating the Fibrintimer A, KC 10 and KC 40, the Electra 1000 C and the ACL were run with the respective ~agents from Baxter Diagnostics. (Miami. FL. USA~ and Instrumentation Laboratory as well as the Behringwerke reagents in parallel, when appropriate. The results show a good reproducibility of measurements. Intra-and inter-assay coefficients of variation (%) for control and patient plasma samples were between 1.6 and 4.4 for PT (%) using Thromborel S, 0.7 and 3.4 respective 0.6 ~nd 5.2 for aPTT (sec) using Pathromtin and Neothromtin, 1.1 and 8.8 for fibrinogen determination (g/I) using Mnltifibren (all reagents from Behringwerke). The method comparison shows good agreement between the methods evaluated, i.e. there are good correlations of results between the Fihrintimer A and the KC 10 / KC 40 for PT (r = 0.971), aPTT (r = 0.875 and 0.954 using Pathromtin and Neothromtin, respectively) and fibrinogen (r = 0.964) as well as between the Fibrintimer A, the Electra 1000 C and the ACL (r-values about in the same order). These results show, that the Fibrintimer A is well suited for routine coagulation testing.

body_text.text: An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for the quantitative determination of human cross-linked fibrin degradation products (D-dimer) in plasma has been developed. The assay has been evaluated using purified D-dimer from plasmin treated fibrin clots, which was free from DD/Ecomplexes. The monoclonal antibody selected as catching antibody (mab DD5) is highly specific only for cross-linked fibrin degradation products (cross-reactivity <0.00006) and allows accurate determination of D-dimer even in the presence of high concentrations of non cross-linked degradation products as e.g. during thrombolytic therapy. Furthermore, the mab DD5 binds preferentially to early degradation forms of D-dimer. Therefore, the assay probably rather is measuring actually liberated Ddimer, reflecting the "activity" of the thrombo-/fibrinolytic system. However, this has to be established in future studies.

The bound D-dimer is detected using peroxidase-conjugated rabbit antibodies against human fibrin(ogen). The assay is performed within less than one hour (15 min for each incubation step). The minimum detectable amount of D-dimer in plasma was 0.5 tJg/I. The aim of the present study was to investigate the use of duplex sonography in noninvasive assessment of the efficacy of urokinase therapy in 20 patients with DVT of the ileofemoral veins. In all subjects ascending venography was performed within 24 hours before starting the urokinase therapy. The promotion of the resolution of venographically confirmed DVT was then evaluated by repeat duplex sonography within 24 hours using a 7,5 MHz sector duplex probe with an integrated pulsed 3 MHz frequency Doppler system connected to a Konton Sigma 44 equipment. Juding the duplexsonographic findings this noninvasive method helped to define the termination or continuation of the thrombolytic therapy in 18 of 20 subjects. In 2 patients duplex sonography failed to estimate the present status. Early total recanalization of ileofemlral veins within 4 and 5 days of thrombolytic therapy was detected in 3 patients suggesting the interruption of the urokinase therapy. The data of this investigation indicate that duplex sonography is a useful tool in assessment of the efficacy of thrombolysis in DVT reducing ascending contrast venography examinations during thrombolytic therapy. This method is non invasive, it can be carried out repeatedly every day with no risks and helps to improve the duration of thrombolytic therapy in DVT. Despite these advantages of duplexsonographic examinations ascending contrast venography examinations are still necessary to evaluate indications of thrombolytic therapy and to estimate prognoses in patients after thrombolysis of DVT.

Albert since blood contains PAI-I, the fast acting inhibitor of t-PA and plasmin inhibitors, such as alpha-2-antiplasmin, the immediately inactivation of these inhibitors after blood drawing is especially important in the estimation of t-PAactivity. The standard procedure, as suggested by many authors, consisting in immediate acidification and centrifugation of the blood samples is not easy to handle. We studied in 29 healthy volunteers a more practicable technique in sample collection and processing. Blood samples, taken at the same time, were prepared by both, the standard procedure and the modification. In modification, blood was drawn in plastic tubes, prefilled with sodium citrate for 0.05 mol/l and acetate buffer pH 3.9 for O.i mol/l as final concentrations. Samples were centrifuged at once and after a 1 or 2 hours incubation on ice. The samples then were stored at -70~ and assayed after at least 4 weeks at once. The results we obtained showed no significant difference between the standard method and our more practible modification, also after a storage over 1 or 2 hours on ice. It is known that F.VIII:C activity decreases if plasma samples are stored for several hours at room temperature (RT). However, storage time and temperature between blood collection and analysis sometimes vary considerably and cannot be defined. As the influence of storage en~litions on different assay systems may vary, we decided to carry out the forlowi~g study: plasma (a) of healthy volunteers (n = 12) and (b) of hemoi~hiliaes receiving F.VIII-substitution therapy (n = 10; range of F.VIII activity: 33 to 121.5%) was stored at -20~ 4~ and RT for 6 hours. The F.VIII:C determinations were carried out with a one stage clotting assay and a chromogenic substrate method (IMMUNOCHROM F.VIII:C). In several cases, the clotting method gave higher values than the chromogenic assay: (1.) in healthy volunteers versus substituted hemophiliacs; (2.) in plasmas stored at -20 ~ versus plasma at 4 ~ or RT; (3.) in plasmas with F.VIII activity > 120%. However, the correlation of both determinations was acceptable (r = 0.866, n = 173). When F.VIII concentrate was added to lyophilized plasma (to about 200%), both occurs in some plasmas during blood sampling, which only influences the clotting assay. Interestingly, the loss in F.VIII:C activity during storage is higher (1.) in healthy persons than in substituted hemophiliacs; (2.) in the ehromogenic than in the clotting method; (3.) in samples stored at 4 ~ than in samples stored at -20~ or at RT. Our study showed that loss in F.VIII:C activity is least at -20 ~ in both assay systems. It even appeared, that a slight activation of the coagulation system during storage of plasma at -20 ~ occurs, since in the clotting assay the mean F.VIII activity in the plasma of substituted hemophiliacs. stored at -20~ is even higher than the initial value. In sununary, if an average decrease of F.VIII activity of 11% can be accepted, plasma samples can be stored at room temperature for 3 hours. We developed a new clot lysis assay performed on microtitre plates to evaluate the individual fibrinolytic activity induced by various plasminogen activators in plasma. By adding plasma to Thrombin and either Streptokinase (SK), Urokinase (u-PA) or t-PA in Tris-suffer, clotting and subsequent fibrinolysis can be visualized and quantified by measuring the optical density at 495 nm. plasma from i00 persons without a history of thromboembolic diseases as well as plasma from 200 patients with a history of thromboembolic diseases where assayed in the described way. The results were compared with immunologic and functional measurement of Fibrinogen, PAI, t-PA, Antiplasmin and global clotting assays as well as with the results from the venous occlusion test. In 80% of all plasma samples a quick fibrinolytic response to all three fibrinolytic agents could be observed.

In plasma from patients with a history of thromboembolic diseases the fibrinolytic response was impaired in 6% with SK, in 4% with u-PA and in 6% with t-PA and u-PA. In plasma from patients without a history of thrombosis fibrinolytic response was impaired in 12% with SK, in 2% with u-PA and 6% with t-PA. Prospective clinical studies are required to determine whether these findings lead to consequences in choice and dosage of specific Plasminogen activators especially in patients with an impaired fibrinolytic system. Euglobulin lysis time (ELT) is a global test for the study of fibrinolysis, useful to measure both baseline and stimulated fibrin dissolution in a milieu largely depleted of natural inhibitors of fibriuolysis, To obtain reliable re~uhs preparation of samples as well as blood sampling and procedures of performing ELT must be well standardized. The aim of this study was to evaluate the influence of storage of plasma and euglobulin precipitates (El>) on ELT by testing samples obtained both before and after 10 min of venous occlusion (VO). From 20 healthy subjects (21-40 yrs) EP were obtained from diluted and acidified platelet-poor plasma (PPP) by centrifugation at 1500g, for 10 min at 4~ and careful removal of surnatant. Diagnosis of congenital or acquired coagulation disorders is made by proven clotting methods including overall clotting methods and various specific tests such as chromogenic substrate assays. The development of new drugs controlling haemostasis requires pharmacological studies in animals. The aim of this study was to transfer established procedures to veterinary medicine. In species such as rat, rabbit, cat, dog, sheep and pig, coagulation profiles were done by activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), prothrombin time (PT), thrombin time (TT) and chromogenic substrate assays for the determination of plasminogen, the so-called antiplasmin activity and heparin (via an anti Xa test) by commercially available reagents. Binder* PGEl-infusion therapy has been shown to improve hemodynamic parameters in pts. with severe ventricular dysfunction. As a side effect bleeding complications have been described. It is further known that an increase or decrease of cardiac output (CO) might reactively influence the fibrinolytic system by alteration of liver metabolism of its main components, t-PA and PAl-1. To prove possible influences of PGEl-infusion on the fibrinolytic potential we investigated 11 males with dilated CMP and severe ventricular dysfunction treated with maximal tolerable PGEl-infusions (group A) for their possible alterations of systemic blood pressure, heart rate, pulmonary arterial pressure, CO, cardiac index (CI), as well as t-PA and PAl-1 plasma levels, and compared the data to those obtained from 4 otherwise comparable and similarily treated pts. without PGEl-therapy (group B). As compared to conservatively treated pts. in PGEl-treated pts. a significant improvement of CO (A: from 5.1 to 6.2; B: from 4.9 to 4.9) and of CI (A: from 2.6 to 3.2; B: from 2.4 to 2.4) could be demonstrated. However, t-PA antigen, PAl-1 antigen, as well as PAl-1 activity did not show any significant alterations of their preand posttreatment plasma levels in both study groups. From these data it is concluded, that infusions with high dosages of PGE1 do not influence the fibrinolytic potential despite significant alterations of hemodynamic parameters. Furthermore, data obtained from human umbilical vein endothelial cell cultures (HUVEC) investigating possible PGEl-mediated alterations of tPA and PAl-1 expression have shown no effects. Therefore, bleeding complications during PGEl-infusions seem to be mainly due to the known platelet inhibitory action of PGE1 and can not he attributed to a profibrinolytic effect of this substance. Several prospective studies have shown that plasma fibrinogen (Fbg) is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular ischemic events. Bezafibrate (Bzf), a lipid-lowering drug, is able to decrease Fbg levels in diabetic hyperfibrinogenemic patients. This study was aimed to evaluate if the modifications of Fbg levels induced by Bzf administration in healthy subjects are related to changes of clotting and fibrinolytic parameters. Ten healthy non-smoker volunteers (5 women not on pill and 5 men, 36-45 years) with plasma lipids and hemostatic parameters within the normal range for the age were investigated. The study was performed according to a randomized cross-over design by two sequential 30 day-treatment periods respectively on Bzf (400 mg of Bzf "retard" daily: "Bezalip Retard", Boehringer Mannheim Italia -BMI-Milan, Italy) and on placebo, preceded and separated by a 21 day-wash-out period. Blood samples were obtained on the first and the 30th day of each period. The following parameters were determined: Fbg by automatic apparatus (ACL, Instrumentation Laboratory -IL-, Milan, Italy), fibrinopeptide A (ELISA, BMI, Milan, Italy), cholesterol (Chol), triglycerides (TG) and HDL-cholesterol (HDL-Chol) by refiectometric method (Reflotron System, BMI, Milan, Italy), plasminogen and alpha2-antiplasmin by functional methods (ACL, IL, Milan, Italy). Fibrinolytic activity was assessed before and after 10 min of venous occlusion by determination of: ELT, t-PA and PAl-1 activity (amidolytic assays, Kabi Vitrum, Molndal, Sweden), t-PA and PAI-1 antigen (ELISA, Biopool, Umea, Sweden) . No changes of different parameters were observed during placebo administration. A sigrfificant decrease both in Fbg (-15.7% + 11.58, p<0.05) and in Chol (-15.0% + 6.90, p<0.005) was observed after 30-day Bzf treatment. On the contrary, no significant changes in the other clotting and fibrinolytic parameters or in TG and HDL-Chol were found. These data suggest a direct influence of Bzf on hepatic synthesis of Fbg, without modifications of other proteins of the hemostatic system.

body_text.text: Center of Heart and Thrombosis Research, Clinica Medica I, University of Florence, Italy The relatively high incidence of thromboembolic complications in the neonatal period requires investigation of the fibrinolytic capacity and the individual dosis of thrombolytic agents. In this study, fibrinolysis of newborns was evaluated by using new methods. Venous blood samples were obtained from 32 healthy newborn infants within the first week of life. A chromogenic substrat assay was used to determine plasminogen activity and a global screening test (Fibri Screen Assay,Baxter) to evaluate whole plasma fibrinolytic potential. Clot lysis time was measured kinetically by using a micro clot lysis assay (Lewis et al., Thromb Res 64,223,1991) . The results were compared with those in adult plasma. Plasminogen activity (60.7%• and fibrinolytic potential (62%• were found to be significantly lower in newborns. The newborn plasma required 6 times higher concentrations of urokinase to start lysis and complete lysis time was two times longer. There was only a poor correlation between plasminogen activityand fibrinolytic potential or clot lysis time. Data from the present study emphasized again that fibrinolytic response of newborns is significantly reduced. Additionally impaired clot lysis was not only due to low plasminogen activity. The variability of values from patient to patient suggests that urokinase requirement must be considered for each patient individually. The micro clot lysis assay could be a simple method for this purpose and also for monitoring thrombolytic therapy. Fifty-nine patients with coronary heart disease allocated fur PTCA showed significantly elevated thrombin-antithrombin III complexes (TAT; ~ = 2.3 vs. 1.4 ng/ml) compared to 19 control patients who showed normal coronary vessels by angiography. There was also an impaired fibrinolytic capacity determined by venous occlusion compared to patients without coronary arteriosclerotic lesions. In a prospective part of the study blood analyses were done before PTCA, 24 h, 48 h and 3 months aRer PTCA. All patients underwent a control angiography after 3 months and restenosis was documented in 24 patients. Both patient groups with and without restenosis showed an activation of coagulation after PTCA by increased TAT. The increase of D-Dimer was prolonged in patients without restenosis compared to patients with restenosis. The ratio D-Dimer/TAT significantly decreased 24 h and 48 h after PTCA indicating prolonged disturbed balance between coagulation activation and fibrinolysis in the group with restenosis. Fibrinolytic capacity (venous occlusion)was markedly lower only in the restenosis group before PTCA compared to controls (x = 5.7 vs. 13:3 IU/ml). The present findings suggest that low fibrinolytic capacity may be a risk factor for developing restenosis after primarily successful PTCA. In previous investigations, a variety of polyanionic compounds have been tested for their tissue-type plasminogen activator (t-PA) releasing effect in vitro and in vivo. Of these substances, unfractionated heparin (UFH), pentosan polysulphate (SP54), the polysulphated bis-lactobionic acid amide derivative LW 10121, enoxaparin-sodium, defibrotide, sodium humate (Na-HS), ammonium humate (I~ffI4-HS), and the polymeric oxidation product of caffeic acid (KOP) proved to be effective (K10cking H-P, Hamostaseologie 11:76, 1991) . Attempts were made to rule out an effect of these compounds on the acute activity of plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAl-l), an important component of the antithrombotic defense mechanism. In vitro studies indicated that the incubation of polyanionic compounds with PAI-I had no effect on its ability to form t-PA o PAL1 complexes, and that the incubation of these substances with preformed ,t-PA o PAl-1 complexes does not modify their stability. Furthermore, the influence of polyanionic compounds was studied in rats after intravenous bolus injection of 10 mg/kg each. Within 5 to 10 min after administration of the following substances, a decrease in acute PAl-1 activity was found: UFH: 53 -+ 18 %; SP54: 89 -+ 9 %; LW 10121:38 +_ 20 %; enoxaparin-sodium: 75 -+ 2 %; defibrotide: 60 • 16 %; Na-HS: 58 • 17 %; NH4-HS: 32 _.+ 23 %; KOP: 31 • 23 %, resp. The decrease in acute PAl-1 activity is explained by complexing with simultaneously released t-PA.

body_text.text: We have evaluated the sensitivity to tPA-induced lysis of clots prepared from plasma preincubated in vitro with therapeutic concentrations of unfractionated heparin (UH) or 3 different low molecular weight heparins (LMWHs). Labelled fibrin clots, prepared from plasma containing UH, fraxiparine, reviparine, encxaparine or saline, were incubated for 2 hours at37 ~ in PBS containing t-PA (0.1 and 0.5 ,u~/ml) and plasminogen (20 /Jg/ml). The extent of clot lysis was quantified by counting the residual radioactivity of the clots and by measuring D-Dimer levels into the medium. Fibrin polymerization and clot structure were evaluated by means of a turbidimetric assay and by electron microscopic scanning. Clots prepared from plasma.containing 0.5 and 1.0 U/ml of UH showed lysis rates higher (up to 236%) than control clots. Preincubation of plasma with 1.0 IU/ml Fraxiparine, Reviparine and Enoxaparine increased lysis rates induced by 0.1 pg/ml t-PA by 49%,43% and 42%, respectively, over the lysis rate of control clots. Lysis rates induced by 0.5/Jg/ml t-PA were not significantly modified by LMWHs. The effect of UH was not mediated by the inhibition of thrombin as preincubation of plasma with hirudin did not modify clot lysis. We also found that UH modifies fibrin assembly and clot structure leading to the formation of thicker fibrin fibres and clots with large pores. In contrast with UH, LMWHs induced only minor modifications of fibrin polymerization and clot structure. An increase of clot sensitivity to lysis can contribute to the antithrombotic activity as well as to the bleeding complications of heparins. Our data suggest that the early administration of UH along with thrombolytic agents could increase the speed of reperfusion and reduce the risk of rethrombosis. In addition, our results contribute to explain the minor hemorrhagic potential of LMWHs in comparison with UH. An association between plasminogen activators and tumor invasion has been described in various malignancies and recent findings suggest that high u-PA levels in breast cancer tissue predict elevated recurrence rates. Patients and methods : To study the tumor-associated role of plasminogen activators and their inhibitors in gynecologic neoplasms, u-PA, t-PA and PAI Ag levels were determined by ELISA in 224 tissue samples obtained during gynecologic surgery: 189 from patients with malignant disease (152 breast-, 25 ovarian-, 12 vulvar-cancer) and 35 benign tissue samples collected from patients who underwent surgery for benign fibroadenomas or mammary dysplasia.The median age of these woman was 60 years (range 29 to 93 years). Parallel we detemimed the receptors for estrogen (E2R), progesterone (PrgR) and Epidermal-Growth-Factor (EGFR). Correlation was sought between the type, size and differentiation of the tumor, lymph node involvement, invasion of lymphatics, menopausal status and age. Results and Conclusion:u-PA and PAI-levels in breast-, ovarian-and vulvar-cancer tissue were higher than in benign tissue samples, but only the differences in breast tissue samples were statistically significant (.p<0.005). u-PA and PAI did not depend on other established prognosuc variables such as lymph node involvement, tumor size, age or menopausal status. In cases of hemangiosis or lymphangiosis carcinomatosa, PAI levels were particularly elevated. High PAI-levels and EGFR correlate with low levels of E2R and PrgR. No statistically significant differences were noted for t-PA between malignant and benign tissue samples, but high grade dedifferentiated neoplasms revealed significantly lower t-PA levels (p< 0.005). The considerable variations in u-PA and PAl Ag levels can be of major importance in predicting the course of disease and may help in the decision whether adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated or not, particularly in patients without lymph node involvement. However, further follow-up will be needed to prove the therapeutical and prognostic relevance of the tumor associated elevated levels of u-PA and PAI in gynecologic neoplasms.

Cytokines as well as parameters of haemostasis were determined; baseline values were slightly elevated due to the underlying disease. Cytokine increase began 1.5 h following the bacterial lysate injection. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) peaked at 60-fold increased values ca. 3 h following the Picibanil injection. During the fever maximum (ca. 4.5h after injection) interleukin 6 (IL-6) also reached a maximum with ca. 300-fold elevated values whereas changes in IL-t, IL-2 and IL-4 were negligible. Concomittant/y, haemostasis was activated without any relevant consumption. Thrombin-antithrombin complexes, prothrombin fragments and fibrinopeptide A rapidly increased, peaked with 3.5 to 8-fold elevated values 6 to 7 hours after injection and declined to needy initial values 18 hours later. The strong parallelism of these 3 parameters must be emphazised. Analogously to changes in TNF, these increases were comparable but were more pronounced (in level and length) after injection of endotoxin containing lysates than after grampositive bacterial lysates. Fibrin degradation products (FbDP) increased 4.5 to 6 hours after injection up to 2-fold values. FgDP increased simultaneously, declined neady to initial values and increased once more to the 1.3-fold after 24 hours. Without a pdor decline, fibdnogen began to increase 12 h after injection. Protein C declined by 15% whereas antithrombin III remained unchanged. The number of platelets fell by 12%, their activation was measured by means of flow cytometry analysis. Hypercoagulable state after surgery was reported as a reason for postoperative thromboembolic complication. To investigate the contribution of extrinsic pathway to thrombosis the tissue factor (TF) and factor VII level was determined in the plasma of patients after abdominal surgery. Tissue factor is constitutively present in several tissues such as epithelal tissues, brain and placenta, but it is normally not expressed on cells within the vasculature. On monocytes and endothelial cells TF is expressed only as a reaction to inflammatory and immunological stimulation. The plasma concentration of TF is enhanced in several patients with thromboembolic diseases as well as in patients with hypereholesteraemia. In this study, alterations of TF release into plasma after tissue injury during surgery was investigated. "IT and, in addition, factor VII were detected using a sandwich ELI-SA with monoclonal antibodies. Plasma was collected: a) the day before surgery, b) intraoperatively, c) one day and d) five days postoperatively. In contrast to the reported increase of TF expression on monocytes after surgery, the plasma levels of TF were not elevated. Factor VII was reduced in about 70% of the patients intraoperatively. Pretratment values were restored between day 1. and day 5 after surgery. This was correlated with factor VII-activity measurements.

In conclusion, we could not detect a postsurgical TF enhancment in plasma in this study. The evaluation of factor VII showed a decrease that might be caused by consumption in relation to TF expressed on monocytes or endothelial cell. Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by an excessive vasoconstriction of the cutaneous circulation of the extremities, that is reported to be due either to increased sympathetic tone or to abnormal aneriolar vasoreactivity. This study was aimed to investigate, by the study of (3H)NA kinetics, whether the sympathetic system plays a different role in the pathogenesis of vasospastic attacks in patients with primary (PRP) or secondary Raynaud's phenomenon (SRP). Ten PRP patients (8 females, 2 males, aged 38+8), 10 SRP patiettts (6 females, 4 males aged 40+10) and 10 controls of equivalent age were studied. During (3,H)NA infusion, at the opposite arm HBF was evaluated by strain-gauge plethysmography (Periflow SU4, Janssen, Belgium) and blood samples were simultaneously taken from the radial artery, the antecubital vein and a vein of the back of the hand under basal conditions (15 min from the start of infusion), 2 and 10 min after the beginning of a 2 minlasting cold pressor test (CPT). Plasma NA concentration was assayed by HPLC with electrochemical detection. Under basal conditions HBF was not significantly different in the 3 groups, whereas after CPT HBF significantly decreased only in PRP and SRP patients (from 3.0l+0.6 ml/100ml/min to 2.5+0.3 ml/100ml/min and from 3.04+0.7 ml/100ml/min to 2.6+0.4 ml/100ml/min respectively) (p<0.0I). In PRP patients regional NA spillover was higher than in controls both in basal conditions (p<0.01) and~during CPT (p<0.001); on the contrary in SRP patients basal regional NA spillover was similar to that of controls but significantly lower than in PRP patients (p<0.05). After sympathetic stimulation NA spillover became significantly higher in SRP patients than in controls (p<0.05) but continued to be significantly lower than in PRP patients (p<0.01); in fact the percentage increments in NA spillover induced by CPT in controls, PRP and SRP patients were 28.5+6.3, 42.7+11.2 and 34.1+--9.7% respectively . No significant difference was found in (3H)NA regional extraction, total (3H)NA clearance and spillover among the 3 groups throughout the test. Present results suggest that the vasospastic attacks of primary or secondary Raynaud's phenomenon have different pathogenesis: the enhanced activity of the sympathetic nervous system plays a primary role in the primary Raynaud's phenomenon, while an altered local vasoreactivity seems to be a prominent feature of the secondary Raynaud's phenomenon.

body_text.text: Extracellutar proteolysis is one of the important biological activities in multicellular organisms. The wide range of processes entailing this activity includes fibrinolysis, extracellular matrix degradation involving cell migration during embryogensis, angiogenesis, inflammation, tumor metastasis and proenzyme activation such as that of collagenase and stromelysin. Plasminogen activators (PA) play a pivotal role in these processes by converting an ubiquitous proenzyme plasminogen to plasmin. Reflecting the wide range of PA biological activities, expression of PA genes is highly regulated and modulated by a variety of extracellular stimuli such as hormones, growth factors, retinoic acid and tumor promoters depending on the cell type. We have performed a detailed analysis of the cis-acting sequences involved in regulation of the hu-PA gene and found that a hu-PA minimal promoter is regulated by a constitutively active remote enhsncer (-2000/-1870) . We show th~ transcription of the hu-PA gene which is highly expressed in transformed cells and tumours is efficiently activated by TPA and nuclear [c-Jun, c-Ets-1 (p68), c-Ets-1 (p54), c-Ets-2] and cellular oncoproteins (Ha-ras, v-Src, v-Mos, polyoma middle T-antigen, v-rat). Protein-DNA binding and mutational analysis show that the enhancer is at least composed of two separate DNA elements: Ets/AP-1 and a second AP-1 site. Transient expression of hu-PA enhancer/CAT reporter gene showed an interplay of these two elements. Band shift experiments revealed two distinct protein-DNA complexes. In general these results lead to the conclusion that activating oncoproteins participate in the mechanism by which hu-PA gene expression is deregulated in transformed cells.

body_text.text: Steroids and related hormones play an important role in regulating development, differentiation and homeostasis. The hormones exert their regulatory effects by binding to a superfamily of intracellular receptors, which are direct modulators of gene transcription. The human glucocorticoid receptor (GR) is a member of this superfamily. GR has been shown to repress expression of a group of physiologically important target genes, which code for metalloproteases such as collagenase and stromelysin. The expression of the hman u-PA is known to be repressed by glucocorticoids. We present evidence that the target for the negative effect of glucocorticoids is the constitutively active hu-PA-enhancer (-2000/-1870) which is the target for several nuclear and cellular oncoproteins and tumor promoter phorbol ester (I'PA). Negative regulation is due to repression of c-Jun/AP-1 activity through the GR. This inhibition is independent on GR-DNA binding to a GR response element (GRE). A hormone-independent activator GR is a moderate represser of the hu-PA-enhancer whereas a DNA-binding mutant GR (point mutation) shows significantly decreased represser activity. The GR antagonises in a hormon-dependant manner the induction of the huPA-enhancer by oncoproteins. These observations that the GR inhibits the huPA-enhancer provides a framework for understanding the opposing effects of growth factors, inflammatory mediators and steroid hormones. Aberant expression of the u-PA gene has been implicated in pathological conditions such as inflammation, arthritis and tumour invasiveness. The anti-inflammatory properties of glucocorticoids could be explained in part by inhibition of the AP-1dependent u-PA-enhancer.
