Introduction: Assessment of inflammatory activity in children with Crohn disease is difficult. Most activity indices developed for adults are inappropriate for children, since evaluation of clinical symptoms as a part of the index is inaccurate. A single laboratory parameter might give a better estimate of the inflammatory process. Several parameters, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein and semm orosomucoid, have been suggested as discriminatory variables of disease activity. However, these parameters are not directly associated with the inflammatory lesion. Von Willebrand factor (vWF:Ag), synthesized in endothelial ceils, which are involved in the granulomatous inflammatory process, may give a better insight into activity of Crohn disease. Patients and methods: Twenty-eight children (age 4-20 ys, mean 13.5 ys) with proven Crohn disease (7 children with inactive, 9 with slight, 7 with moderate and 5 with severe disease activity) were examined for factor VIII activity (F VIII:C), yon Willebrand factor (vWF:Ag) and ristocetin-cofactor activity (vWF:Rcof).The factor VIII coagulation proteins were correlated with disease activity index according to van Hees and were compared with inflammatory parameters such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, Creactive protein and orosomucoid.Thirty children were' examined as healthy controls. Results and Conclusion : A highly significant elevation of all components of F VIII complex were found in patients with moderate and severe disease activity. In patients with mild and inactive disease, all coagulation activities were normal. Plasma levels of all components of F VIII complex showed a positive correlation with the graded activity index of van Hees. Among the factor VIII proteins, vWF:Ag correlated best with van Hees disease activity index (p < 0.001 ). Since acute phase proteins are produced by liver cells, whereas vWF:Ag is synthesized by endothelial cells, we postulate that this coagulation factor is highly sensitive in reflecting the inflammatory process in the intestine. The association of antiphospholipid antibodies (APA) with thrombosis, recurrent abortion and thrombocytopenia has been named Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). APS may occur within LES and other autoimmane disorders (secondary APS), or in the absence of any recognized underlying disease (idiopathic APS). It has been demonstrated that APA confers an increased risk of thromboembolic complication to LES patients, but no demonstration of such an increase has been given for idiopathic APS. In 1990, a Registry of patients with APS was instituted in Italy, with the aim to obtain information on the natural history of the syndrome in a large number of cases. 319 patients (80 males and 239 females, aged from 2 to 76 years, median 31 yeats) have been hitherto included in the Registry, referred from 23 Italian Centers. They were 112 cases of APS secondary to LES and 207 eases of idiopathic APS. 47 out of 112 (42%) and 71 out of 207 (34%) cases experienced arterial and/or venous thrombosis, respectively. Among patients with a thrombotic history, venous thromboembolism was observed in 57% vs. 60%, arterial thrombosis in 32% vs.27% and both types of thrombosis in 11 vs, 13% of patients with secondary vs. idiopathic APS, respectively. Deep vein thrombosis of the legs and arterial thrombosis of the cerebral vessels were the most common types of thrombosis in both groups. Thrombocytopenia was present in 22% of patients with secondary APS vs. 28% with idiopathic APS. In conclusion, the data from the Italian Registry indicates that the prevalence of thrombosis and thromboeytopenia in the idiopathic form of APS is similar to that observed in APS secondary to LES.

body_text.text: IMMUNOLOGICAL CHARACTERIZATION OF MONOCLONAL IgM ANTIPHOSPHOLIPID ANTIBODIES.

Lupus anticoagulant (LA) and anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL) belong to the family of the antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL). LA inhibit phospholipid-depandent coagulation reactions in plasma, whereas aCL bind to anionic phospholipids in the immunoassay. Recently, our group has demonstrated that LA and aCL antibodies recognize 2 different lipid-bound/protein complexes, i.e. lipid-bound/human prothrombin and lipid-boand/132-Glycoprotein I (B2-GPI), respectively. These data refer to aPL of the IgG isotype. Conversely, little is known about the immunological targets of IgM aPL, the mor*, so since they are not reported to be related with arterial and/or venous thrombosis, repeated abortions and thrombocytopenia like IgG aPL. Therefore, we evaluated the immunological characteristics of IgM with aPL activity, purified from the plasma of 3 patients (2 suffering from Waldenstrom's disease and one from cryoglobulinemia, none of them with history of thrombosis) by gel filtration chromatography. Two monoclonal and lpolyclonal IgM preparations were obtained. One monoclonal and the polyclonal IgM's were able to prolong dRVVT of human (68.7 and 52.6 sec vs 32.1 see of control monoclonal IgM) but not bovine (35.1 and 33.4 see vs 34.0 see) plasma and failed to bind to anionic phospholipids in ELISA. Thus, they behaved as LA antibodies, directed against the complex of lipid-bound human pmthrombin. The other monoclonal IgM preparation bound to eardiolipin and phosphatidylserine in ELISA and was able to prolong the dRVVT of human (95.7 vs 32.1 see) as well as bovine (101.1 vs 34.0 see) plasma. This prolongation was abolished upon preincubation of the normal human plasma with anti-B2-GPI antiserum, indicating that this IgM was directed against lipid/B2-GPI complex. In conclusion, monoand plyclonal IgM's aPL display similar immunological pattern as previously shown for IgG's aPL. Not all LA patients, however, have a history of thrombosis or will develop thrombosis in the future. Thus, in a retrospective study on 46 LA patients with or without LA-essociated thrombophilia, it was investigated whether the strength of LA measured by routinely used functional and immunological LA tests is a useful parameter to identify LA patients with a high thrombotic risk. The data obtained demonstrate no correlation between the incidence of thrombosis and the concentration of LA antibodies, indicating that routinely used LA essays are rather qualitative than quantitative. Since impaired thrombemodulin (TM) activity in the presence of LA has been suggested to be one of the main causes for LA-associated thrombophilia, it was explored whether the rate of TM inhibition could be correlated to the incidence of thrombosis in LA patients. TM activity was measured using an endothelial cell dependent PC activation assay. Only 2 out of the 46 LA patients showed decreased TM activity. Moreover, in one patient a TM-autoantibody of IgG subclass was identified. Although impaired TM activity in both patients was associated with str~nw tl'gambophil~a, these data indicate that acquirGd dysfunction of ,'~,~ is neither a common feature nor a main cause of thrombophilia in LA patients, Searching for another explanation for I_A-associated thrombophitia it became obvious that activated protein C (APC) requires although anionic phospholipide to achieve its full biological activity. Thus, impaired catalytic activity of APC could be a result of LA antibodies. To verify this hypothesis, an assay for the determination of APC activity in LA plasma samples was developed. APC generated from purified PC was added (0.5 p.M and 1,0 I~M) to LA plasma. After incubation of different times, APC activity waS measured via the rate of FVlll degradation by a one-stage clotting assay using FVlll-deficiant plasma. In all 46 patients studied, a strong correlation between APC inhibiting activity and the strength of thrombophilia was found. From these data it is concluded that LA prevents the formation of the APC complex essential for rapid proteolysis of factors Va and Villa. We suggest that persistence of factors Va and Villa in blood creates a hypercoagulable state responsible for thrombephilia in LA patients. Most importantly, however, the new test described offers a new opportunity to identify LA patients who are at high thrombotic risk. body_text.text: ;ession 46: Neutro )hils and Monoc'~te: Recent studies have demonstrated that the expression of monocyte PCA characterized as tissue factor-like activity is clearly dependent on direct collaboration of stimulated T lymphocytes. The aim of this study was to investigate the role of freshly prepared lymphocyte fractions on monocyte PCA in the absence of exogenous stimuli. From human blood samples highly purified lymphocyte and monocyte populations have been prepared by FicolI-Hypaque density gradient centfifugation and adherence to plastic plates; the B and T lymphocyte fractions were separated by cytoadherence to neuraminidase-treated sheep red blood cells. Mixtures of monocytes and lymphocyte fractions (T and B identified by specific monoclonal fluorescent antibodies: OKT3, OKB19, OKM14, Ortho Diagnostic) were than coincubated for 4 hours at 37 ~C and PCA was measured in a one-stage clotting assay. Several studies have demonstrated the capacity of allogeneically stimulated T-helper lymphocytes to induce human monocyte procoagulant activity. In experiments with murine T cell clones it has been observed that monocyte PCA induction was due to the lymphocytes Thelper type 1 subset. Human T cell clones with T-helper type 1 (Th-1) or type 2 (Th-2) functional pattern have been identified more recently. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of different stimuli on human T-helper subsets capacity el inducing monocyte PCA. Human Th-1 and Th-2 cell clones, derived from peripheral blood of healthy donors, have been stimulated for 24 hours by PHA (1%) in the presence of antigen present cells or by PMA (10 ng/ml) and monoclonal antibody anti-CD3 (100 ng/ml). After removing the supernatant the T cells were coincubated for 8 hours at 37 ~C with monocytes, lreshly prepared from human peripheral blood by FicolFHypaque density gradient centrifugation and adherence to plastic plates. The cell cultures have been analyzed for PCA characterized as tissue factor. Our data indicate thaf monocyte PCA in the presence of PHA stimulated Th-1 type clones is five-fold higher than after coincubation with PHA stimulated Th-2 type clones. Whereas upon exposure of T cell clones to maximal stimulation with PMA and anti-CD3 diffrence between Th-1 type and Th-2 type clones becomes less evident. These results suggest that in humans monocyte PCA might be induced predominantly by type I T-helper lymphocytes under physiological conditions. body_text.text: EFFECT OF PROTEINASES RELEASED BY POLYMORPHO-NUCLEAR LEUCOCYTES ON PLATELET MEMBRANE RECEPTORS M. Meyer (1), K. Bykowska (2), S. Lopaciuk (2), M. Kopec (2), I. Schellenberg, (1), Ch. Str6hl (1) Leucocyte proteinases released under various physiological and pathological conditions modulate platelet function. In order to compare human neutrophil elastase (HNE) and cathepsin G (cat G) with respect to proteolyfic action on platelet membrane receptors washed platelets were incubated with the purified enzymes. Membrane glycoproteins (GPs) were analyzed by SDS discelectrophoresis and twodimensional electrophoresis in combination with Western blotting and immunodetection and by crossed immunoelectrophoresis. Both proteinases rapidly degrade GP Ib producing an Mr 105,000 fragment removing the N-terminal sequence containing binding sites for yon Willebrand factor and thrombin. Only cat G gives rise to a smaller Mr 78,000 fragment. A concomitant loss of ristocetin-dependent platelet agglutination is observed. In contrast to this close correlation between functional and proteolytic effects there is a rapid expression of fibrinogen receptors (aggregation in response to fibrinogen) by cat G (not by HNE) but only slow degradation of GP lib-Ilia complex. Major proteolytic fragments of GP IIIa appear only after 10 -15 min treatment under our conditions. Thus, leucocyte proteinases seem to exert a sequential effect on platelets: first destruction of receptors for adhesion to subendothelium, expression of fibrinogen receptors and subsequent proteolysis of fibrinogen receptors.

Binder Granulocyte elastase (GE) is released from leukocytes stimulated by several coagulation factors and functions as proteinase modulating fibrinolytic activity and degrading extracellular matix. Various leukocyte mediated stimuli induce endothelial cells to produce type 1 plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAl-1 ); therefore both GE and PAI-I are released upon leukocyte endothelial cell interaction. GE could be shown to cleave and inactivate PAl-1 ; furthermore GE and PAl-1 bind to heparin. While heparin dose not alter functional activity of PAI-I, it decreases GE activity. The aim of this study was to analyse the effect of PAI-t on GE heparin interaction. When GE activity was analysed in the presence of PAl-I, heparin had no inhibitory effect, but GE activity was increased. Therefore we investigated the effect of PAl-1 alone on GE activity. When human GE (0.2/~g/ml) w.as inctthated ~.ith PAl-1 (0-200U/ml) in the presence of 0.5M NaCI, GE catalytic activity was significantly increased in a dose-and time-dependent fashion. Maximal stimulation occured after 15 min of preincubation of PAl-1 with GE. Addition of t-PA acclerated the stimulating activity of PAl-1 indicating that t-PA-PAI-1 complexes had stimulating effect on GE activity. This stimulation was also dependent on the ionic strength and was most pronounced at 0.5 M NaC1. Such high ionic strength might occure also locally in vivo, e.g. in the presence of platelets undergoing release reaction. These findings suggest that upon inflammatory conditions not only the plasmin dependent fibrinolytic potential is decreased but also the elastase dependent proteolytic activity is increased.

Therapy generally lasted for 7 days. Furthermore 40 patients underwent thrombolytic therapy with ultra-highdose-streptokinase (UHSK) using 9 Mill. u/6h on 3 consecutive days. Ascending phlebography was performed initially and after termination of the therapy. Complete clot dissolution without thrombotic ~esidues of any hemodynamic relevance resulted in 33% O f all evaluated patients: UK 27%, UHSK 52.5%, rtPA 2S~. back_matter.text: Backqround: Coagulation and fibrinolysis may be activated in cancer patients. It is of clinical relevance, whether plasma levels of activation markers are related te clinical features such as tumor stage or response to treatment. Patients and Methods: In 47 lung cancer patients (15 SCLC, 32 NSCLC), the plasma levels of TAT, F]+2, plasmin-antiplasmin complex (PAP), and D-Dimer were assayed by ELISA before commencing specific antineoplastic treatment. Results: Statistically significant differences were found between limited (LD) and extensive disease (ED) patients (TAT 3.5• vs. 8.1• p=O.O21; D-Dimer 716• vs. 1143• p=0.014) , and between patients reaching complete or partial remission after treatment (GR) and the patients with bad response (BR) to therapy (TAT 2.8• vs. 7.7• p=0.0047, D-Dimer 557• vs. 1146• p=0.0013 ). Statistically significant differences were also found for the molecular ratios of markers, with higher TAT/FI+2, TAT/PAP, as well as D-Dimer/PAP ratios both in ED and in BR patients. Conclusions: The data indicate that in patients with advanced lung cancer and poor prognosis there is a more pronounced activation of haemostasis. The markers TAT and D-Dimer might be helpful prognostic parameters. Furthermore, the interaction between coagulation, fibrinolysis and inhibitors, as reflected by the molecular ratios of their respective activation markers, appears to be altered in advanced lung cancer. In septic patients disturbances in the haemostatic system are observed during the development of multiple organ failure (MOP). 28 septic patients of an internal intensive care unit were observed over a period of 15 days or until death. Sepsis war diagnosed according to the criteria of the Veterans Administration Systemic Sepsis Cooperative Study Group.Patients were classified with respect to severeness and extent of organ failure by the APACHE II-score and the MOF-score as well as in septic and no more septic patient s during the observation time.Among other parameters there were determined interleukin 6, neopterin, CRP, elastase, factor XII, tissue plasminogen activator, plasminogen activator inhibitor, D-dimers, thrombin-entithrombin complexes, and protein C. There was a strong correlation between APACHE IIand MOP-score. All parameters determined from plasma correlated with the severeness of the disease and with extent of MOF. Significant differences existed between septic patients and patients which became non septic during the follow up observation period. Interleukin 6 and neopterin were significant related to parameters of the fibrinolytic system. Fibrinolytic activity could not be detected in plasma. D-dimers probably indicating fibrinolysis in the microcirculation were present in each case.The results indicate that coagulation and fibrinolysis may act as mediators in the development of organ dysfunction in septic patients.

During our studies on the negative regulation of endothelial thrombomodulin (TM) gene promoter by tumor necrosis factor c~ (TNFa) we identified the TNFcr responsive element (TARE) as protein-binding site for the proto-oncogene products c-Ets-1, which has been identified as the cellular progenitor of the v-Ets-oncogene. The c-Ets-1 proteins are located in the nucleus, bind to DNA in vitro, and function as transcription factors. From our results with TM promoter, we conclude that c-Ets-1 is an important regulator of endothelial gene expression. However, our data suggest that either an endothelial-specific member of the Ets protein family or an Ets-associated factor is involved in the negative regulation of the TM promoter by TNFa. In order to identify these regulatory molecules, we undertook a molecular cloning approach using the among all members of the Ets protein family highly conserved DNA-binding domain (180 base pairs) from the e-Ets-1 Cterminal end as a hybridization probe to screen an endothelial lambdagtl 1 cDNA expression library. Six from eight phages which repeatedly hybridized with the c-Ets-1 AatlI-Bal1180 bp probe under high stringent conditions were purified and further analyzed with restriction enzymes by subcloning into plasmid vectors and DNA sequencing. The resulting contigous DNA sequence and deduced amino acid code revealed 100% identity with the c-Ets-1 p68 eDNA. Currently we are using different conventional cloning procedures and PCR cloning methods to identify additional Ets-like or associated factors in endothelial cells. Thrombomodulin ('FM) is expressed on vascular endothelial cells and plays an important role in the protein C anticoagulant pathway by maintaining the thrombo-resistence of the blood vessel wall. We show that in primary human endothelial cells TM gene transcription is repressed by tumor necrosis factor r (TNFa) through a protein kinase C independent pathway. TNF~ specifically represses the highly active TM promoter in transfection assays. The -76/-56 5'-flanking region of human TM mediates both high basal expression and TNFa repression. Protein-DNA binding and mutation analysis indicate that TNFa repression is mediated by an endothelial-specific member of the ETS domain protein family, hJthough c-Ets-1 (p68 and p54) and c~Ets-2 stimulate the TM promoter through the -76/-56 element, their activity is not suppressed by TNFa. c-Ets-1 can compete and override TNF~ repression in a concentration dependent manner. We propose that either a different cell-specific member of the ETS domain protein family, or an Ets-associated co-factor, is the target of the TNF~ signalling cascade in endothelial cells.Haemostasis Research Unit, Max-Planck-lnstitut fOr physiologische und klinische Forschung, Kerckhoff-K]inik, Bad Nauheim, Germany
